الموضوع طلع كبير :D
مكنتش متخيل ان دا يأثر على البرامج الكبيرة كدا .. he's a valve developer :)
He would just use Assembly (inline) and the FPU instruction set and write the function to the lowest level, I' m sure at valve they use a lot of SIMD, FPU,..etc.
I am not sure the complexity of using assembly is rewarded with any real gains in this case. I mean that would probably yield the same machine code.

That's appears to be right. Inline assembly is slower. Compilers have powerful optimisation

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9601427/is-inline-assembly-language-slower-than-native-c-code
I guess both processors and compilers are more complex nowadays and writing your own assembly tends to get in the way of compiler's optimization.

Well, If you know what are you doing, then inline assembly won't be slower, ever. Unless you're writing an advanced ray-tracer or complex 3D Renderer, computer vision,,ec, you should  notcare about speed.
Your app does not have to be that advanced for speed to be important. Small losses can easily add up and become a bottleneck in a loop.
